basisSection.title: Lawful Basis for Processing Personal Data
basisSection.intro: In order to process personal data, you must have a lawful basis to do so. The lawful grounds for processing personal data are set out in Article 14 of the DPA. These are:

basisList: Necessary to protect the vital interests of a person.
Necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest.
In the legitimate interests of the company/organization (except where those interests are overridden by the interests or rights and freedoms of the data subject).

transparencySection.title: Providing Transparent Information
transparencySection.intro: Businesses and organizations that process personal data must provide individuals with information about the type of processing that is taking place and who is carrying it out. At a minimum, this information must clearly state:

transparencyList: Why you are processing the data.
What legal basis you rely on to legitimize the processing.
Whether or not the data will be transferred to other organizations or individuals.
How long the data will be stored.
The existence of the individual's rights under data protection, including rights to access, correction, erasure, restriction, objection, and portability.
